I want it to completely replace my current digital camera. But it ended up I have to take 2 cameras to a party, one hanging on my neck the other one in my pocket to satisfy my video recording needs. What a shame!!

Reviews.Title: great camera except...
Reviews.Author: Roc
Reviews.Content: Our specific camera had a problem and seemed to frequently wrongly select the right most auto-focus point.  It also had a ton of hot pixels (maybe 80?!?) in the sensor on 30 second long exposures.  We had almost elected to keep it anyway (since manual selection of a single auto-focus point seemed like an ok solution), but then we tried the camera out in very low light conditions. This camera (or at least the one we had before we returned it) had terrible noise at high ISO and terrible color in low light conditions.  If you will never use over ISO 400, and never take low light wide open aperture 10 second shutter exposures at night, it is probably still an excellent choice.  I think ours was a rare anomaly with the weird auto-focus problem.  When it picked the correct point, the subject was always in sharp focus.

Reviews.Title: Fabulous, light and accessible
Reviews.Author: seise
Reviews.Content: I love my new D3000. I've only recently gotten big into photography, and after having joined the college Photography Society and playing with what they had, as well as stealing my father's Olympus on occasion for our trips around Ireland, I NEEDED to get my own camera. As described, it's lighter than the Canon and perfect for someone just starting off with digital photography, and is sick of the regular point and shoots. Can't stop me from snapping now!

Reviews.Title: Great product Highly reccommended
Reviews.Author: Ginnifer L. Earls
Reviews.Content: Im brand new with using SLR camera's, yet this one is simple and produces amazing pictures. I definitely recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Value; Superior Lens
Reviews.Author: Frederick A. Rice
Reviews.Content: I was in the market for a Digital SLR after having a Sony P & S for about 5 years. The Sony was fine but I had always had a rather sophisticated film camera and wanted the flexibility again offered by manual overrides. I have been pleased, the camera is easy to use although I really have not mastered the details thus far, but they are there. What is lacking is a way to learn them, I have been planning on attending a course but as yet have not found one that fit my schedule or location. I now have three lenses; a wide angle zoom, the standard zoom and a telephoto zoom and haven't even figured when to use which one.Will check back in when I learn more.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3000
Reviews.Author: lonewolffenris
Reviews.Content: This product is amazing, it is incredibly easy to use and simplistic in design. I would recommend this product to any one who is interested in photography whether it is as an armature or as a professional.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Steve Long
Reviews.Content: I am a newbie to the DSLR world and, being a technie, I researched the heck out of the cameras available at a beginner level for someone with a limited budget.  The D3000 was the standout from all the cameras I looked at.  Now that I have it and have used it, I must say it delivers!  The colors are vibrant, detail is crisp, and the camera is so easy to use.  Only thing missing is the ability to shoot videos, but if you really want/need that, you can get the D5000.  If you are looking for a nice camera that won't break your bank, this is the one for you.

Reviews.Title: Canon G9 versus Nikon D3000
Reviews.Author: RJ from PH
Reviews.Content: I just returned the D3000 because I didn't think it has as good or better picture quality as my older Canon G9. I have taken some amazing pictures with my G9 but the D3000 certainly didn't compare to it. I was really shocked because I expected a big improvement. I tried  the 3000 on auto and some scene modes but the pictures didn't appear that sharp even though I braced it more than enough for a steady shot and a lot more than I need to with the G9. All of the pictures on the D3000 were taken with the kit lens 18-55 so maybe it's just not that good on scenic pictures.

Reviews.Title: Fast, fun, and great pics
Reviews.Author: D. Abel
Reviews.Content: Our old point & shoot was replaced by this kit. Great autofocus and fast shutter. After the 1-2 second delay from our old camera this is a real joy to use (especially for fidgety kids). The included lens is good for inside pics - relatively close. I recommend the 55-200mm autofocus zoom lens as a necessary accessory for outside shots (the kids play soccer). One caution, professional reviews talk about the multi-point focus providing depth of field focus for foreground and background objects. For action shots, keep your main object [kid] centered to make sure they are in focus.

Reviews.Title: Great Buy for It's Class!
Reviews.Author: Jocelyn Yan "jamcam"
Reviews.Content: After wanting, for the longest time, to own a DSLR, I finally bought the Nikon D3000.  All the modes and features given in the D3000 are easily accessed and understandable.  It took me awhile to figure out how to use the manual mode, but once I did it was amazing!  As many have already heard, the Nikon D3000 is probably the best beginning DSLR anybody can get.  It gives you professional quality photographs (sharp images) for a much cheaper price tag.  I have come to love my Nikon D3000.  I will definitely continue to tote it around with me everywhere until I decide to level up.  I recommend this to everybody!

Reviews.Title: DSLR convert
Reviews.Author: Paul T. Deegan
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to give to my wife for her birthday. She's an avid SLR hobbiest and although she's no professional, she knows and applies more than basics to her shots. I wanted to get her a camera that would allow her to do everything she knows how to do, but not be intimidating in control and features. I looked between the Nikon and Canon and eventually went with the Nikon because it had about the same features with a better price. If I was more concerned about upgradeability I probably would have purchased the Canon. The 18-55mm zoom lens is extremely versatile and the features are great. It basically shoots instantaneously when you hit the button, and the three shots per second work fantastic. Overall it has been everything we wanted in a camera, and the results speak for themselves, she has shots that look professional (she says it was all the camera). A nice bonus is that even for its size, it's fairly light weight. I would reccomend this camera for any hobbiest looking for a good digital camera and you don't need video.

Reviews.Title: Great Starter DSLR
Reviews.Author: T. Hoffman
Reviews.Content: This camera is amazing.  Has a ton of manual features but also full auto.  Autofocus is fast and quiet, but the kit lens is not a sufficient lens.  I will be buying an 18-200mm lens to get a good all round lens.  Picture quality is amazing, feels great in your hands.  Definately the best starter DSLR on the market for the features and money.

Reviews.Title: My new hobby!!!
Reviews.Author: Sean M. Branch "Sean"
Reviews.Content: I am all about having hobbies.  And now that I own my first DSLR, the D3000, I can definitely say that I will be taking up photography.  I love this camera.  I am learning more about photography every day using.  If you want to get started with DSLR, this one is a great choice!

Reviews.Title: Gr8 camera
Reviews.Author: JK "JK"
Reviews.Content: Its really gr8 camera. I have Canon SD1000 camera, but recently I went to one of the live show and the photos which I captured were not satisfactory, so I was looking at SLR option and I purchased this. Recently I went to New york trip and this camera help me a lot to capture really very very nice photo. The night photo of New york city from Empire state building are very awesome. I would really recommend this cam.

Reviews.Title: Good camera for the money
Reviews.Author: theKGD
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my wife after hearing her complain about a smaller and slower point-and-shoot camera. My wife misses the smaller camera's size when lugging it around to different events, but this camera rocks in comparison to everything else. It's a great camera to get started with for a DSLR style camera.

Reviews.Title: My first DSLR, I love it.
Reviews.Author: Laura E. Halfacre "kimonoloco"
Reviews.Content: This was my choice for the first SLR I've ever owned and it does not disappoint.  This camera was taking high-quality pictures immediately out of the bag and I haven't stopped learning about it and taking great pictures since. The modes are great to learn from but within a month of using it almost every day I started just using the Manual mode because it allowed me to learn even more and have fun with the camera! Ive been taking shots in RAW format and using the software that came with the camera to convert and tweek the RAW files, works great. The largest I've printed so far were 8x10 but even those were perfect in quality.The only thing I don't love about it is the lower quality of the display screen.  It can trick you into thinking things did not turn out as you had planned.I would purchase this one over again, its a great starter DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Non-Technical Review - This is a Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Bold Consumer
Reviews.Content: EDITED to say that I decided to take a 3-week trip overseas. My camera was a superstar! I couldn't have been happier. People, strangers, kept asking if they could look at it. The pictures turned out great. An officer on the cruise ship asked if I needed him to "set it" for me. I didn't, but I let him take a closer look at it, which was really what he wanted. I was amazed at how interested people were in it.When I returned and put my pictures online for friends and relatives, one, who is an excellent photographer, asked if he could use some of my photos, because his pictures of Jerusalem weren't as good as mine since he had used a less advanced camera for his. Those pictures do really look good. I couldn't have asked for anything better, other than being a better photographer, of course.Earlier, before my trip, I wrote:I'll leave the technical reviews to others who know what they are talking about. I appreciate and respect their expertise. All I can tell you in my review is, I love my new camera!It's a step up from point-and-shoot, but doesn't require that you make photography an obsession or even a serious hobby. Most people who want a really nice camera but don't want to devote their life to photography will probably find this model will be an excellent choice. It takes great pictures without a lot of fuss or serious study.Years ago I studied photography and had some experience, if not expertise. Then I decided I just wanted a point-and-click for a while. This time I wanted one step above the point-and-click, but I really don't feel the need to be overly creative right now. This model has the ability to do a lot more than I will ever do with it.While it would be fun to just whip out one of those point-and-clicks which I could always carry around in my purse, my son told me I would be happy about a minute and a half with it, so I choose this one. I'm so glad I did.Nikon is my favorite brand in cameras and I wasn't disappointed. The quality of the camera is excellent and the instructions are clear, as long as you take them step-by-step, not that I ever do that. I bought this camera and a photo printer and some other electronics all at the same time and was overwhelmed with user manuals, instructions, etc. That's because my personality demands that I do too much at once. Just take it one step at a time and I think you'll love this camera, even if you are an electronic klutz like me.Now I'll turn you back to the technical experts, who will give you real advice you can use as you make your purchase.

Reviews.Title: Nikon is the Best
Reviews.Author: J. Cable
Reviews.Content: I own a significant collection of Nikon 35mm cameras and lens and in my move to digital equipment there was no other choice except to continue with Nikon. Once you become familar with the Nikon System, no other photographic system measures up. The D3000 provides that same confidence. The camera is of excellent manufacturing Quality and the design is superb. Just pick the camera up and it handles as an extension of yourself and just falls right into proper position for taking outstanding pictures. The menues are are intutive and are very easy to read. Even for a beginner in digital photography, the camera will virtually assure that you will take outstanding pictures. If you are a beginner in digital SLR photography, buy this camera. You will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Easy Transition
Reviews.Author: Thomas Cozzi
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera kit about a month ago as my first DSLR. I had been using point and clicks for years and I always had a great deal of dissapointment. The D3000 was a very easy transition from point and click to DSLRs. It is very user friendly and offers many of the features you would get on any old camera (highly polished in comparison though). It also offers ease of use to someone, like myself who is interested in photography but doesn't know much of the technical "stuff".This camera can be as easy as setting it to AUTO and taking fantastic pictures. If you do as I did and try to learn a few technical aspects of photography, you will see that this camera can be used to take absolutely stunning technical shots.I find that the ergonomics of the body are great, it just seems to fit in your hands as though they were made for each other. I tested out many other cameras before this purchase and found this one to be the most comfortable by far.I would also like to comment on price. I have read many reviews that says it is overpriced but, you get quite a bit for what you are paying for. I think the price is just fine for what is included

Reviews.Title: For the money and ease of use, great camera for the beginner!
Reviews.Author: RE Guy
Reviews.Content: My wife & I treated ourselves to this camera as gift to each other.  We are novices but read other reviews and checked other sites and we are happy with our choice.  Plus with DVD we were able to get started and shoot nice pictures right away. I feel the assistance you get with the menu and help screens make it such that you can find most of your answers right away on the camera.  One thing to consider is to purchase the 2 lens kit as immediately it became apparent to us we needed the 200mm lens.  We could have saved a few dollars by buying the kit with both lenses and the DVDs come with it as well.

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: Rachael Gordon
Reviews.Content: I had been using point and shoot and digital cameras for the past 10 years and was disappointed with the quality and delay when pressing the shutter button.  Although the the Nikon D3000 is an entry level camera, it takes professional looking photographs.  The images are beautiful.  The guide on the camera is very useful, and the camera is easy to use.  It is also light for an SLR.  The viewing screen is  a nice size and you can zoom.  I would recommend this camera to anyone!

Reviews.Title: Nikon d3000
Reviews.Author: Andres Campos Monteros
Reviews.Content: its a great camera..  great resolution and easy to use menus. Its easy and intuitive for those who dont know much about ISO, Exposure, and other technical characteristics of photography. But its equally good for those who do know about camera specs and want to use it in manual mode.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3000
Reviews.Author: Jefferson C. King
Reviews.Content: Indoor pictures with poor lighting have exceeded my expectations.  Also, it was delivered before Christmas as promised.  Thanks.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3000
Reviews.Author: J. McClelland
Reviews.Content: This is a great choice for moving up from a compact camera. The difference in picture quality is stunning. I've had no problems with it and it was not difficult to learn how to use the menus, etc.

Reviews.Title: Good DSLR
Reviews.Author: ACE
Reviews.Content: As the beginner model, this camera is very easy to use. Also, since its a DSLR the picture detail is so much better than regular digital cameras. It is a little bulkier but the picture quality is way better. Great camera for the money

Reviews.Title: DSLR
Reviews.Author: loonyme
Reviews.Content: Everything I wanted from my first DSLR. Light, not bulky and usable by anyone from a novice to someone who wants more control.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera and Easy to Use
Reviews.Author: D. Macdonald
Reviews.Content: Received this for Christmas, 2009.  I am not a photog, but I have owned film SLRs in the past.  This is my first Nikon.  This camera is an excellent "point and shoot" for beginners like me, but also seems to have a lot of potential uses and effects that will keep me busy learning for the near future.  Very user-friendly, and comes with abundant supporting materials, including two DVDs.  So, if you are beginning to get into serious photographing (me, after many years away from it) this would appear to be a great camera to get.  You can work your way to more complicated and satisfying uses at your own pace, and yet use it right away as a "point and shoot."  For my purposes, just perfect.Cameta Photo service was great - on time and well-packed.  They followed up with a satisfaction e-mail.  I have not had to use their services again as nothing has gone wrong, but they seem to be professional and concerned.  Amazon, as always in my experience, was also great.

Reviews.Title: D3K great value
Reviews.Author: Richard M. Provost
Reviews.Content: After using the Nikon D3000 for about a month, and over 500 pictures, I can only report that it is worth every nickel of it's price ($500 on 12/4/09).1. Easy to use.2. controls well laid out3. Kit lens AF quick and silent.4. Size reasonable for small hands (mine).5. Ability to take Nikon 'F' mount lenses (AF or not).While there is the occasional 'oops' moment, errors are easily corrected, and, of course, being digital, errors deleted with no expense incurred. Can't say that about film cameras.In addition to the kit lens, I have bought from a friend his Sigma 70-300 lens. While it is designated as an AF lens, as it does not have it's own motor, it isn't on the D3K. Manual focusing is a bit of a pain, as is having to learn how to do it all over again. But when I get it right WOW! Nice crisp image.The only real criticism is not about the camera itself, a star performer. It is that lack of a REAL manual. The 60 page 'manual' merely highlights the cameras' many controls and menus and does not go into detail about them. The Main manual is a  216 page PDF  file loaded onto a PC and called a Reference manual. I call it the Users Manual, and the little 60 page thing a Quick Reference. The 'Dummys' book I bought on the D3K has a lot of useful information but having a PRINTED manual would have been better than having to buy my own hard copy.

Reviews.Title: Impressed!
Reviews.Author: C. Corarito
Reviews.Content: I knew I wanted a DSLR and after a few months of debate, I decided to go for the D3000. I was tempted to buy a used D40 but the improvements made to the D3000 were hard to ignore. I ended up buying the D3000 in a bundle on Black Friday which saved me about 150 dollars! As a college students, I was beyond happy to save the money.The features include almost anything I need (there's only one feature missing: a color selection tool that my dad's Canon has but the D3000 doesn't) and the portability is incredible. I am still in shock about how light the camera is.For a beginner like me, having the D3000 with an extra telephoto lens is perfect for learning the ropes and hopefully taking a photography class with. I highly recommend this for beginners and perhaps intermediate photographers. Advanced and professionals photographers probably would require more heavy duty equipment.

Reviews.Title: Great DSLR
Reviews.Author: V. Mamnani
Reviews.Content: This is my first slr camera. I am happy that I made this purchase to get the slr camera. Picture quality is too good.

Reviews.Title: Spend the extra money you wont be sorry!
Reviews.Author: R. hewitt
Reviews.Content: The D3000 is a camera that will carry you from beginner to advanced photography. The price on Amazon was the best and it was here in a flash. After using a Nikon 35mm for the past 25 years this is Heaven. You cant go wrong with this one in this price range. If you are going to spend within $100,s of the price for a lesser camera, spend a $100,s more for this one.

Reviews.Title: Nikon D 3000
Reviews.Author: A. J. Ghiraldo
Reviews.Content: I have been an Olympus fan for some time now, but have always known about the Nikon camera quality. I am delighted with my purchase, for my first Nikon and first Digitla SLR, it is a perfect starting point, I see this camera will be with me for a long time.

Reviews.Title: Brilliant for a beginner like myself
Reviews.Author: Christopher R. Foltz "coasteraddict"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera because I love photography and for a while now have dreamed of getting an DSLR.  I have played around with a lot of the features on my various Point and Shoots but I wanted something better.  After going through a lot of reviews, questioning my friends with DSLRs already and knowing my budget I purchased the D3000.  I was not disappointed.  I am no expert on photography and am frequently going to webpages and books to see the best ideas for certain shot situations but this camera so far has done very well for me.  It gives you everything you would need to start out and learn the functions.  it is slightly lighter than a lot of the the other SLRs out there which for me is excellent since I travel a decent amount and makes carrying it around these places no problem.  One thing I thought could have been better is the Guide mode which pretty much is an easier way to use the different settings (portrait, landscape, etc) modes on your camera, and if you don't know how to set the camera in these modes already then maybe you should either do some more reading, or go back to your point and shoot (which also has some of these functions).  Overall I am so far extremely happy with this camera and can't wait for my upcoming trips to really push the envelope of the types of shots I take.

Reviews.Title: Great buy!!
Reviews.Author: James A. Jacob "Jim"
Reviews.Content: Nice Camera for the Photograher that wants to upgrade from their point and shoot. It takes very nice pics and uses all Nikon lenses.

Reviews.Title: Somewhat Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Michael K. Williams
Reviews.Content: After much research I narrowed my choices down to the Canon TOS and the Nikon--looking to spend under $500. I didn't need a high megapixel rating so I chose the (discontinued?) D3000.I had used a Nikon 35mm for many years and loved the sharpness of their lenses. When I discovered that the Canon was in short supply just before Christmas, I ordered the Nikon.It has many more features than I'll ever use. The camera seems to be of quality construction and is a bit bulky and heavy, as one would expect from a DSLR. I was happy that it could use the 52mm lens accessories from my 35mm Nikon. I often use a polarizing filter for outdoor scenic shots.My main complaints are:1 - The flash is very weak with fall-off at just a few feet. If you're going to shoot a lot of pics indoors you'd better get an add-on flash (it has a hotshoe.)Pictures tend to come out with orange skin tones (usually correctable using computer software.)2 - Lens sharpness is just average. I hate to say it but my cheaper Canon Powershot A1000IS takes sharper pics at 2 mp than the Nikon. Also, the Canon has more "snap" with brighter colors. This can be adjusted in my computer, but why should I have to?3 - Manual focus in semi-dark or very cloudy conditions can be tricky. I shot some pics in the rain and many of them were blurry (I assume from camera shake.) This surprised me, but is correctable I suppose if I change ISO settings.4 - Getting the supplied carrying strap on it is a major undertaking. I finally gave up, threw it away, and used the neck strap off my old 35mm Nikon with metal snaps.My opinion may change after more than a couple of sessions, but with 40 years of camera experience, I doubt it.Some of you may find this to be nit-picking so you should make your own decisions and carefully study other user reviews.Would I buy this camera again? The answer is probably not. I know this is a low end DSLR but for the money I expected better.

Reviews.Title: Very nice beginner camera.
Reviews.Author: Nathan Trail "4alex6"
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for about a year now and I feel like now is a good time to finally review it. First of all, this is a very nice starter and affordable DSLR for any beginner photographer like myself. Before I got this camera I had very little experience in taking good photos; normally I was just the one to get a compact flash camera to use on our family trips. However the sad thing about this camera is that I didn't know that it didn't have video recording capabilities. So if you are able to spend a little extra money on a new DSLR, then I would advise you to go with getting a D3100. Now, time to do the pros and cons of the camera:-----Pros:- very affordable- very good image quality- very easy to use and not very complicated- very well made; (didn't get too damaged when it fell onto a hard tile floor from four feet)- battery life is decent- portable-----Cons:- flash isn't the best- the strap that comes with it isn't good (the camera fell after the strap came lose around my neck)- no video recording capabilities- not very good indoorsOverall this is a very nice camera with a very nice lens. After owning it for about a year, I do think that I will be upgrading once I have the money to a D5100 or to a D7000 since I have become more experienced with DSLRs.

Reviews.Title: Good but not great. Get D5000 instead.
Reviews.Author: Gaurav Srivastva
Reviews.Content: I had this camera initially but since I'm an amateur photographer, the pictures weren't really mindblowing. The pictures were specially bad in low light conditions unless you go into manual mode.I then got a D5000 for comparison and was impressed with the pictures with that camera at low light settings. D5000 also has scene mode (more standard shooting modes like on beach/snow, pets, etc) and has CMOS sensor along with video at 720p.So, while this camera is all right, I'd suggest D5000 if you can afford it (especially if you're an amateur photographer like me).

Reviews.Title: Useless indoors, extreme shutter delay (half-second, at least) means you'll miss the shot
Reviews.Author: E. Cannaday
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying I have a Nikon D40 for my personal use. It is incredible; I love it. It shoots perfectly in all conditions and is a dream to use (my undergrad is in photography/fine arts but I need none of those skills to get great images with the D40). However, this D3000 SUCKS! I got this for work, since we needed a good camera for marketing purposes, and it's atrocious. It has a LONG shutter delay - at least half a second, maybe longer - which means you WILL miss many shots - smiles will be fading smiles, IF YOU HAVE KIDS FORGET IT, etc... I did a three-day photo shoot - about 2,000 images - inside our building, with excellent professional supplemental lighting, etc and very very few of the images are usable, even with exposure correction in Photoshop. They are way too dark, and have tons of noise and multicolored grain. I am returning this and saving my company the money. Our OLD Canon is better than this clunker.It might be OK outside, but even cellphone camera photos taken in sunlight look great. That is not a test.

Reviews.Title: Great easy flash and no flash modes! not fantastic for dark interiors at high iso
Reviews.Author: college kindler
Reviews.Content: Great easy flash and no flash modes! not fantastic for dark interiors at high iso. at 1600 and 3200 iso it can begin to look like a blurry image no matter how still you are. but other than that, fantastic! speedflash works without a hitch, many different nikor lenses fit on here, all AF-S ones in fact. Bokeh is very cool with the stock lens too. Wayyy better than all point and shoots less the face detection since its an older model. better than similar Canon, Olympus and Sony at comparable price points for the amateur because the VR and the autofocus is very easy and the AUTO modes take much more vibrant shots that are much more color balanced than the other brands I tested.

Reviews.Title: Great beginner camera to grow into
Reviews.Author: SmallOffice
Reviews.Content: I had not used anything but a point-and-shoot camera in years and so wasn't sure how much I would really use all of the features in a DSLR camera.  Therefore, I decided to buy the Nikon D3000 because it is affordable and still good enough to allow me to learn.  You might read criticisms about this camera based on the fact that it isn't the latest technology.  Semi pro cameras costing over a thousand dollars from just a few years ago used the same imaging chip and their images where considered top-notch then.  The nature of the technology (CCD chip as opposed to CMOS chip) means that this camera cannot take movies or show your subject beforehand on its screen.  This is not a defect - it's just the nature of this technology.  Those writing critical reviews because the camera is not physically capable of doing what they want should have read the specifications more closely.  The fact is that this technology is far more capable than most of the people who use it, making it a good affordable camera to learn on.  Don't be suckered into spending money on megapixal envy - if you are even considering this camera the chances are you aren't a good enough photographer to be constrained by its technology.  I've had a lot of fun!

Reviews.Title: Don't get it as your "for everything" camera.
Reviews.Author: Zihna
Reviews.Content: To start: I am not a professional photographer. This review is more for people that never owned a DSLR camera and may not know what they are getting into. I am just a person that wanted a good camera to take great pictures. This is not a great camera for someone that travels a lot and wants to take a camera because it is quite big and heavy. Some situations need quite the adjusting to get a descent picture. And in low light the camera is pretty much useless.Pros:- Takes awesome action shots outside. (I have two dogs and the pictures of them playing and running around the backyard came out AWESOME!- I was also able to take great black and white pictures inside, but you have to play with the settings for quite some time before taking a picture.- The menu has a beginners guide that kind of guides you through the settings. But again - do you really want to have to set up the camera each time before you take a picture?Cons:- The flash is useless. But you can buy a separate flash.- If you try to take pictures of a person with dark complexion the person will look a lot darker on the pictures. That happens to me inside and outside. I am pretty pale but it actually gives me a nice tan. lol.- Its bulky and heavy to a point I don't want to take it with me anywhere on vacation.- The lens it comes with has barely any zoom. It zooms somewhat if the object is close by, but if you want to take a picture of something in a distance it will not zoom in much at all. My daughters $100 camera has a much better zoom than this one. As a matter of fact my Iphone 4s has a much better zoom than this camera - or I should say the lens it comes with.PS: You can buy a zoom lens for $250 and up though to fix that problem!- It has no video function even though the menu and manual have video option. Booooooo!- You can not use the view finder on the display. You have to go way back in time and put your eye on the camera. Talking about old school lol.To sum it up! I am not gonna say its a garbage camera. Its possible that a professional photographer that knows how to set all the settings ISO etc and has the time to set the camera before each picture will take some great pictures. However, this is NOT for the average person that wants to take the camera on vacation and take family vacation pictures on the go. Its too big and complicated. If you want to get into photography this may be a good camera because it has the beginners menu that will assist with the settings.If you want a everyday camera I would advice you to find a Point-and-Shoot camera. This is what I did after 3 years of having this sitting in my closet collecting dust and only come out for taking pictures of my dogs playing outside every now and then. I did take it with me on some vacations where it usually stayed in the room because nobody wanted to carry it around. lol. Plus my daughter was getting irritated that I always wanted to take her camera on vacation with me lol.So again - it may be a great camera for getting into professional photography but for the average Joe just get something normal. You will save a lot of money and get the pictures that you want. I am going to keep this thing and who knows maybe one day when I retire I may have the time to learn everything about ISO and shutter speed and what not which is required to know if you want to get your money worth out of this camera. ;)Yes you can set it on Auto and point and shoot but the pictures will not always come out as you expected.

Reviews.Title: on to digital
Reviews.Author: D. Roller
Reviews.Content: had a nikon f - I miss film but this looks great - fabulous optics -will add more as I work with it

Reviews.Title: great camera, although a little dated, works great when paired with a decent lens!
Reviews.Author: sufuhonda
Reviews.Content: i bought my d3000 in 2011 before i took a trip to florida, i had no previous experience using a DSLR before i purchased mine, and it was fairly easy to learn on. since it doesn't have as many options as higher models it was less to learn about.this camera works great if you just want quality pictures and do not mind shooting in auto, but once you have some experience and start using manual you may want to upgrade.i havent made the switch yet but im looking into the d7000.all in all this camera is fantastic and i love it, but it isnt for a professional more of an amateur photographer

Reviews.Title: Got it for $210
Reviews.Author: dobri
Reviews.Content: Target was selling the D3000 for $301.98 brand new! So, I'm new to photography and i decided to buy it because of the awesome deal. When i went to buy it the sales guy told me that they had no more. so he sold me the display version for 30% off so i ended up getting it for $210 then a $30 3 year warranty to make sure it nothing goes wrong. so far its pretty awesome.  and i ended up buying better lens for it, the 55-300 lens for $359.Pros:Takes amazing pictures if used properly, so you don't need an expensive camera like a nikon D7000 to make terrific pictures, just the right accessories. You just have to know how to use the nikon D3000 to make great pictures. What i did is i got the nikon accessory bag that came with a nikon school dvd. I highly highly recommend for all beginners to get it. i got it for $50. the bag is terrific to hold cleaning supplies, other lenses and flash accessories. After you get the bag, please watch the video! It is gold for anyone new or even intermediate to photography. As i mentioned i am pretty new and after watching a 160min video i felt like a pro. it explains anything and everything one would want to know about photography. I loved it.Next, the 18-55ml lens is terrific, but, after about an hour or basically after watching the video,  you will realize that those lenses are just not strong enough and you will find yourself needing a stronger lens. I recommend getting the nikon 55-200ml lens. They come with VR, which is vibration reduction, so when your hands shake the photo is not affected, it is amazing. You can get these lenses for $200. I went a little further and got the 55-300ml lens for $360 just so i can have the extra distance which is useful for far away things such as animals, buildings, or people. Also, memory card is not included with the camera. The max is 8GB. I recommend that one because you never know how many pictures you will have, plus it is only $30. Finally, to complete your set would be a decent flash. For flash i would just recommend searching around here on amazon and see which would best fit your photographic needs. As for me i plan on getting a flash soon but haven't found one yet.Cons: Not much but it is difficult to take pictures at night because i still haven't gotten the hang of it. And by at night i don't mean of people i mean pictures of buildings or cars or just places. Other than that i LOVE this camera. But if i find something else i will be sure to update this review.

Reviews.Title: They're right
Reviews.Author: Srisagar
Reviews.Content: I've read most reviews here on this product and they are about right. Just keep in mind: The only reason You'd want to purchase this instead of D3100 is because of the IR option.

Reviews.Title: Great gift for daughter
Reviews.Author: C. McBroom
Reviews.Content: This camera has worked out well for us so far.  My 13 year old daughter has a beginning interest in photography so we needed a camera that was more of a learning model.  I don't know anything about D-SLR cameras but so far this one has fit the bill for her.  I recommend purchasing the dvd that teaches the features of the camera as well instead of relying on the manual.

Reviews.Title: Excellent purchase
Reviews.Author: Wilmer Maldonado
Reviews.Content: Excellent equipment.  It come as I saw on the post. The resolution is the best and the size better .

Reviews.Title: camera
Reviews.Author: W. G. Cline "momag"
Reviews.Content: I really like my camera. The ease of operation is great and it has so many different setting. The lens is detachable, so zoom can be added.

Reviews.Title: Awesome beginner camera
Reviews.Author: SarahJareczek
Reviews.Content: So many amazing settings and easy to navigate features! The instructions are super straight forward as well. I am completely psyched on this, my first dslr camera.

Reviews.Title: New camera for future wife as wedding gift

Reviews.Title: Nikon D3000 Review
Reviews.Author: Smore412
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera back in December 2009 as a bundle package, it was the first DSLR I have ever owned. I got the D3000 body, and two lenses, the 18-55mm AF-S DX NIKKOR f/3.5-5.6G VR, and 55-200mm AF-S DX VR Zoom-NIKKOR f/4-5.6G IF-ED. For the past 4 years I have been using this camera non-stop, as it plays a large role in my college studies. I highly recommend the D3000 based on the following:  1. Guide Mode: a tutorial-like setting, which walks you through how to get a certain type of shot  ( lighting, shutter, aperture, etc). This mode is great for beginners, who are still trying to figure  out their cameras.  2. Battery life: The battery lasts for about 1400 pictures at the highest quality setting(RAW).  3. Image Clarity: Ignore what you hear about this camera being "entry-level quality". This camera is  capable of capturing incredibly sharp, crisp, vivid imagery. (Almost as good as some of your higher  quality camera, when in the right hands!)  4. Low Price: When you consider the vast amount of amazing features that this camera offers, the list  price is truly a steal. Especially if you buy a used model in good condition.  5. Comfort: I have used both Nikon as well as Canon products, and personally feel that the Nikon models  feel better in the hands while shooting. This model in particular is very light weight and compact.I use my D3000 mostly for children, animals, night clubs, HDRs, and extreme action sports such as bmx and snowboarding.  This camera can handle almost anything you throw at it, and when additional pieces are used (external flash, external lenses) this camera really delivers.My only negative thought about this camera is that I wish it had a video option like most of the higher end models. But as an entry level DSLR, I have no complaints towards the Nikon D3000.

Reviews.Title: 4/5 alone, but 3/5 when compared to the D3100! Get the D3100, it's a much better camera for just a little more!
Reviews.Author: Ace

There is no video function, which seems standard for most cameras, let alone one of this price. Relatively low MP considering I have paid half as much for other cameras with 12-14MP. I wish I would have just bought the D3100 which seems to have rectified all of the issues I mentioned as well as others mentioned by more experienced photographers. I needed a new camera, this one was on sale and came with everything I needed to get a bit more serious with my photography (just a hobby and way to record my world travels), so I bought it, but it makes more sense to shell out the extra $50-$60 and get the D3100, which is a much better camera but did not go on sale until AFTER this one arrived. Of course you will lose out on the "bundle" deal (case, extra lens, memory card and DVD's) but you will want a much larger memory card anyway (and they are pretty cheap) you can get the lens you actually want (I wish it came with a wide angle or something) and a case that would fit to what ever lenses/filters and such you do decide to get.That being said, the case is great, relatively large, but it fits everything nicely. The memory card is a decent size (8GB, but you could buy a 32GB or higher for next to nothing). Most serious photographers carry multiple lenses though and this case only fits one, maybe two if you don't carry the battery charger and such. That's fine for me though, as I only really need the one right now, again. The Camera is a 4/5 for me, but a 3/5 once I realized what I could have gotten for a few more dollars...

Reviews.Title: Perfect camera for a non-enthusiast busy parent
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were sick of missing those precious moments when you are trying to get two young kids to smile nicely and look at the camera at the same time, or catch that fleeting moment of joy. So we gave up on the idea of a "nice point-and-shoot" and bought a real camera. We leave it on full auto 99% of the time and the pictures look amazing compared to your last point-and-shoot. We get instant response from the shutter and the colors look really good even indoors at night with flash (a little dim, tiny yellow, but miles above what we were used to).I do wish it had video capabilities as I would love to see what that looks like. Also, at first I wished you could frame your shot on the LCD screen, but once you get used to a view finder (been a long time since I used one) you tend to prefer it.The kit is nice, you get the two lenses you really need. I might eventually pick up a prim lens, but no real need for anything else. The memory card is high quality (class 10) so photos are not slowed down by slow write speeds (the Walmart version of this kit has a slower card). The bag is just big enough for the body, two lenses, and recharger...so no wasted space, but you'll need a bigger bag if you plan to grow your lens collection.This camera exceeded my expectations on image quality given its "entry level" status in the DLSR world. In my opinion, it is the perfect camera for the non-enthusiast who just wants good photos WITHOUT having to spend a fortune on equipment, wheel around a camera suitcase and spend a ton of time learning how to operate a camera. It's the Honda Accord or Toyota Camry of cameras.

Reviews.Title: Nice entry level, basic camera. Good with outdoor photography or portraits.
Reviews.Author: SuperPhotoPerson "SPP"
Reviews.Content: First off, If you're considering buying this camera for a starter, go for it. The price is great. Don't be turned away by the lack of features or the "low" megapixels, because it's good to start simple at first. If you take your time figuring out the controls of the camera, you can shoot photos that will stand out, photos that are much better than a phone camera or point and shoot will give you. It isn't about the equipment, it's about the person.  This camera is all a beginner would need. It is lacking video recording, live view, and some other small features. These aren't needed to take photos. A video recorder is used to take videos. A camera is used to take pictures. If you think you need live view-you don't. You won't find a professional photographer that uses live view, for a reason.  As far as comparing this to a similar Canon entry level DSLR, you will find in these lower end cameras that Canons, when used in full automatic, take harsher photos. Nikon takes warmer photos. I have used several Canon entry level cameras, and several Nikon entry level cameras. They both have a strong build quality, but Canons seem more sensitive to constant use. I've seen Canon's that have the grips peeling off, etc.  This camera's sensor generates quite a bit of noise. Anything above 400 and it gets obvious. I always shoot with my ISO at 100, and even at 100, sometimes when it's dark and the room, you can see noise in shadows. The shutter speed is not a problem, 3 fps is plenty to capture a shot. The problem is the buffer. Even with a class 10 card, it takes anywhere from 5 to 10 seconds to clear off the buffer of the 3 pictures taken in that second.  Auto focus is extremely slow. One benefit, the camera comes with an auto focus light assist. Otherwise, the camera takes 2 to 3 seconds of hunting back and forth in order to focus, and even after that, half the time it's on the wrong subject. This isn't my lens, it's the software in the camera. Just the other day I was waiting for a large butterfly I spotted out front to land on a flower so I could capture it. I immediately switched to aperture priority, and knocked my aperture size up to about f5. The butterfly landed, and I quietly moved over to position my camera by the flower. I looked in the viewfinder, and saw the most awesome shot. Of course, it was out of focus, so I went to focus it. The auto focus missed, so I tried again. By the time it locked in on the flower, the butterfly was gone and flying down the street. I would have used manual focus, obviously, if I knew that was going to happen.  The appearance of the camera is nice, being so compact. With the included lens, the weight is pretty much evenly balanced with the battery in the camera. The camera is quite a bit lighter than the majority of DSLR's, which is nice. I've dropped the actual camera once, trying to carry it and change lenses while walking. It hit the corner, and I was sure I had damaged it. I picked it up, and everything worked just fine. It left a small (3mm or so) impression in the case. I've used this camera in damp conditions before, it has no problem.  Battery life is pretty good. It will last for about 1000 raw photos without the flash, and about 200 raw photos with the flash. Recharge time is amazing, it only takes about 3 hours on Nikon's quick charger. I do not take mass photos, I see quality being more important than mass, so the battery lasts quite a long time. I've thought about buying an off brand battery grip in order to take portrait photos easier and improve my current battery life.  The onboard flash is horrible. It doesn't work well as an actual flash, and it doesn't illuminate the scene very well. It eats battery life. I bought the Neweer TT560 Speedlight, Neewer TT560 Flash Speedlite For Canon/Nikon Digital SLR Cameras, and it works so much better. Sometimes I will even use the onboard flash just to trigger the Neweer flash, knowing it will hardly effect the photo as long as I adjust the power output from the Neweer flash to compensate. Works great as an off camera bounce flash.  As far as the lens, it's good for portraits and some macro photography. It has a very nice bokeh and a large aperture. It isn't a "low quality" lens just because it comes as a kit. Of course, being an 18-55mm lens, it doesn't have very much range. I like to shoot a little bit of sports, mostly baseball which is quite stationary, so I bought Nikon's 55-200mm f/4 ED VC AF lens. It preforms pretty well. Wish it had a larger aperture, but anything above f/4 and you have to pay, quite a bit more. If you're worried about CA, or vignetting, I haven't seen any. This lens is sharp, and has crisp colors. Quality is iffy, after the first year or so the auto focus started making a terrible noise if you accidentally touched the focus ring while it was focusing. When I say touch, I mean touch. Not restricting. Just touching it. It makes a horrible screeching sound. It's worked and given me no problems but the screeching sound, so It may or may not be a problem. I don't know yet.  Over all, the camera is good for entry level, and you won't need to upgrade until you start doing low light shooting. You can spend thousands on lenses and put them on this camera, they will work fine and you will realize that 10 megapixels is all you need unless you are doing major cropping or huge prints. After three years of owning it, it is showing no signs of anything wrong with the body itself. I expect to use this camera for several more events. I have shot several baseball seasons with it, several holidays, several basketball games, some more sports, and other similar stuff. It serves its purpose as a camera, and it does it well. I would have given this review five stars if the small problems with the lens never showed up, the flash preformed better, the auto focus preformed better, and the sensor didn't show as much noise as it does.

When we entered the dSLR market, I was open to all high end makes and shopped around to find one that met our minial requirements. The D3000 has met and surpassed our requirements and many we didn't know to look for. I think it serves as a great starting point into the dSLR world and will give a perspective and appreciation for the few features that it may not have, though it may take a few years to discover them. This model has the Guide feature which explains right on the screen what the different settings are used for and how to adjust them so its like having the instruction manual built into the camera, a big feature for dSLR newbies! I'll skip and leave tech specs and arcane details to the photo-philes and stat geeks but suffice it to say that this camera won't disappoint anyone but an advanced user and at the price point, is a rewarding choice.

Reviews.Content: Purchased the Nikon D3000 for my teenage daughter, who is an avid photographer. She loves the camera and it does everything she requires from it. It is a great entry level DSLR and the experience purchasing from Amazon was a delightful one.

Reviews.Title: Was looking forward to D3100
Reviews.Author: Avid Reader
Reviews.Content: I was looking forward to upgrading from my D40 to the D3100 until i found that the latter does not feature a grid overlay on the viewfinder screen (which the D3000 DOES have!) The grid only occurs on the live view screen on the D3100. I would never use the live view screen. Why they left it off on the D3100 is beyond me. I do a lot of architectural and interiors shots and find myself using my old film Nikon F3 simply because it does have interchangeable screens!

Reviews.Title: A very nice DSLR camera
Reviews.Author: James Dainis
Reviews.Content: I have been in photography for over 40 years including my own darkroom work.  When it came to moving up to digital photography, I chose the Nikon D3000 based on reviews and information I had picked up at various photography sites. While not a full blown professional camera, costing thousands more, it has all the functions that I need to get professional results without all the extraneous bells and whistles. I find the exposure metering to be very accurate so that even an amateur can get very goods results even if only shooting in Automatic mode. A very nice camera indeed.  Two things it lacks are Live View on the LCD screen and Video capture. If those are important, go to the later D3100.

Reviews.Title: Only Slow Operating Speeds Let it Down
Reviews.Author: Steve Woo
Reviews.Content: The D3000, which I purchased about a year ago, was the first DSLR I have owned.I have had a lot of fun with it and learned a lot in the process while also taking some really great shots.  Even so I was tempted to score it down to 3 stars instead of 4 for one issue that was not apparent to me when I first started using the camera.  More on this later.It is so easy to operate that even if you do not wish to make any effort beyond the built in guide mode you should quickly find you start to learn something of the basics of digital photography.  The image quality is high and I did not find anything particularly wrong with the noise at high ISO's that others have complained about.  Being a beginner to DSLR's (as I am sure most people considering this camera are) I think you will probably find it an improvement on whatever point and shoot camera you have been using and leave it at that. OK - I know that "not knowing any better" is hardly a good excuse for what others have claimed is a camera flaw - but the bottom line for me is that noise at high ISO's did not spoil my enjoyment of the camera.With the addition of a couple of lenses (a fast 35mm prime and a telephoto) I have found I was able to get good quality pictures while doing everything from taking snapshots around the house to tripod mounted landscapes and at one point I even made a make shift light box and experimented with some product photography.  In all of these activities, while I was often reminded the D3000 was an entry level camera (e.g. no exposure bracketing), I cannot say I ever felt cheated or completely prevented from doing anything I wanted to do.So why consider given the camera 3 stars?  Something I did not initially notice but which has started to spoil my enjoyment of the camera is the slow operating speeds when the active d lighting feature is switched on.  Active D lighting is a really useful feature that helps improve pictures taken in high contrast situations - something I find myself doing more and more often.  In these circumstances the camera operation is so slow as to be useless for any sort of active target shooting (like kids and/or pets playing).  These are the scenes I have the opportunity to shoot at the moment ... and the D3000 makes it harder and less fun than it should be.So, I would probably chose a different (more expensive) camera if I were to make the same decision today. But I feel the D3000 does such a great job at such a good price in all the other scenarios I have used it, that I think it is worth 4 stars.  It does what it does just great.

Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR camera.  After reading several reviews on Amazon, I decided on this camera...I am glad I did.  The camera is easy to use, takes great pictures, and I have already ordered the 55-200mm telephoto lens for closer shots.  Once you go DSLR, you will not go back to point-n-shoot.

Reviews.Author: Gilbert Reyna
Reviews.Content: My New Nikon D3000 DSLR is great!  I must confess though, I am a newbie to Digital Photography.  I have have been using the Nikon D3000 for two weeks.  I have been taking pictures using the  automatic Modes on the Nikon D3000.  These Auto Modes make it easy for someone like me to take clear and bright pictures.  I'm  looking forward to learning the other Manual Modes so I may continue taking better photographs in the future. Reviews.Title: Great "everyman" DSLR
Reviews.Author: Lindsay Brunner
Reviews.Content: Let me start out by saying that I LOVE this camera!  I'd been wanting a DSLR for probably ten years, and I happened to see a commercial when this model came out and just couldn't believe the price, I was expecting to have to spend at least $1200 one day if I ever decided to actually buy one.I'm not a professional photographer by any stretch, I know nothing about white balance or ISO or any of that, but this camera makes me look like I do.  It's auto function takes better pictures than any point and shoot I've ever owned. I don't have the hand stability to be able to use some of the modes (especially night shot) without a tripod, but with one, the pictures have turned out wonderful.I only have two gripes, both of which I knew going in, and are so insignificant they're barely worth mentioning.  This model of Nikon does not have a video display on the back screen, you have to look through the viewfinder to take pictures.  That was kind of weird at first, but now I don't even think about it, nor does it bother me.  Also, the camera is big, especially for anyone who has only ever held a point and shoot. I'd handled Nikons before, and was prepared for the size, so I was fine with it.  I actually think my hands are steadier with more to hang on to. Just know that this is not a camera you can shove in your purse and head out for the night! Anyone who's unsure should handle one at an actual store before buying!

Reviews.Content: I bought this camera after borrowing a co-worker's Nikon D60. I loved that camera and my friend had to pratically pry it from my hands. So after some research I took the plunge and ordered the Nikon D3000. The Nikon D3000 is a wonderful camera. I take it everywhere. It is extremely easy to use. Reviews.Author: Amy & Jacob
Reviews.Content: When I heard that this was a great camera for starters, I was worried that it would be too basic. No need to worry, it has a lot to offer!This camera is perfect for me. It's a great size and great price. Plus, it's packed with useful features.My favorite feature so far is the ability to crop and edit photos and create smaller images from within the camera menu. I'm capable of doing it myself on my computer, but I get too busy sometimes. I'm sick of having thousands of unedited, unusable photos on my hard drive. This way, I can choose my favorite shots and share them immediately, as well as save a few for more advanced editing if I have the time.The camera does a good job of allowing you to have a range of control. If you're looking for D-SLR picture quality with little to no effort, there's a mode for that. If you want to be in full control, there's a mode for that, too. Plus everything in between.I'm very happy so far!

I've bought a couple of new lenses and both work great with the camera.The only thing I would have liked to have seen were Live Preview on the LCD and Exposure Bracketing. Both of these features could be added through the firmware, and they are present on similar models, so there really isn't a reason not to add them except to encourage people to upgrade. All in all these are minor issues and maybe Nikon will even issue a firmware update down the road to add these features.The couple of missing features aside I am very satisfied with this camera and would buy it again.

Reviews.Author: Geoff Puterbaugh
Reviews.Content: I am an amateur photographer, at best.  I used to have the Nikon D40X, but it disappeared in the hands of a thief.  So I saved my pennies for a while, and finally I went out and bought this Nikon D3000.It is startlingly good.  I'm not sure what, exactly, the Genies of Nikon have been up to, but this camera is a hell of a lot better than the D40X, and the D40X was a hell of a good camera!If you are looking through the reviews here, the most interesting review (for me) was the one by the guy who bought the Nikon, disliked it, traded it in on a Canon, and came out preferring the Nikon he had originally rejected.  Why?  Well, he said something almost mystical: the Nikon pictures were more "involving" --- they invited the viewer into the scene.I've found the same to be true with my Nikons.  People will say, "Great picture!" and I'll be thinking "It's just a picture from my Nikon."A fantastic camera!  Everyone who works at Nikon deserves a glass of champagne!  :-)

The picture quality is awesome. Doesn't do so well in low light areas w/o flash. You have to learn how to take great pictures with flash. The value is great for a DSLR but if you have the extra cash, spend it on the D5000 instead. If you are short on cash,though, this is the Nikon quality you are going to get. The display is big and somewhat easy to use although it doesnt feature live display. It can be a pain sometimes but I got used to it. If you can afford it, buy the D5000, though for the under $500 DSLR this is the best your going to get. Great starter camera, though ill probably buy the next best thing in 3 or 4 years.

Reviews.Title: New Buyer Review - so far so good! Lovin it!
Reviews.Author: Tonupboy "Tonupboy"
Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR so my review is geared towards the newby audience such as myself. This camera takes great pictures and easy to play around at first. I really appreciated the professional reviews, but some tend to forget that this is an ENTRY-Level DSLR and should be treated as such fairly. I am impressed with the build quality and the lens kit. Right away, I charged up the battery which only took an hour and 30 min. and then I started shooting away at my kids playing and my pets. I also took a couple of macro pics which turned out nice and detailed - considering these were shot using the AUTO mode and in the evening - indoors. I find this camera quite satisfying for my everyday needs - a definite step up from my Canon point and shoot - I still use those for social settings and not bulky. The D3000 learning curve is easy when you use the auto mode, but the guide mode helps too for more features - then you have the manual mode which I am interested in for those cutom shots. The camera is not that heavy and fits nicely on my hands. The battery life is good - but always have a spare - which should be standard these days. There is NO video mode so keep that in mind...whats the point? And I heard the video mode for the D5000 is an after thought. This is stricly still photos, folks! So far so good - I can't wait to try out outdoors, which this camera is supposed to excel at!

Reviews.Title: Nikon going in the wrong direction
Reviews.Author: Harry W "Harry"
Reviews.Content: I owned a D60 but I gave it to my sister. Bought this D3000 for myself since it seemed to be better than the D0 specs wise. Boy was I wrong. The pictures from this thing are terrible compared to the D60. Now the D60 itself needed a lot of ISO twiddling then it came down to increasing the depth of field in indoor settings. With the D60, I typically always used to shoot at f10-f16 at ISO800 with in body flash to get a better DOF and D60 did a very good job of handling & suppressing the noise at ISO800, however with this D3000, the pictures at ISO 8000 are turning out to be garbage with too much noise showing. If you are interested in only potraits, you might be OK but for shots where some subjects are 4-5 ft behind others in indoor settings, this camera is going to make it virtually impossible to take good pictures in that setting.The quality of the LCD screen seems to have dropped too..This is going back, I think I am going to order another D60 while it is still available.

Reviews.Title: Not worth your hard-earned $$.
Reviews.Author: D. Contos
Reviews.Content: Updated 8/19/10: Nikon just announced the D3100 Nikon D3100 14.2MP Digital SLR Camera with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 AF-S DX VR Nikkor Zoom Lens last night.  The new sensor suggests a decent increase in image quality (more resolution/higer ISO' improved processing)over previous entry models (D40-D40x-D60-D3000). If you want usable DSLR video and if the image quality pans out the way it should, then this is the entry model for you.  If you don't care about the video, then the D40 is still the way to go - though the D3000 has dropped in price, so maybe not so objectionable now depending on the price, condition.  .02----original review-----------A. Little is right if you're going to treat this DSLR as a fancy P&S; camera, but I think the point of buying a camera of this type (as opposed to some of the cheaper P&S;'s) should include: being able to get better IQ, take faster action shots and to shoot in darker conditions.  We can't minimize the D3000's reduced noise handling ability in relation to the less expensive and older D40 it purports to replace (the third such attempted replacement, I may add) ([...]).  You simply can't take good indoor shots (or darker) without ugly flash glare or more expensive lighting at ISO 200 on these models (can you do it at 400?).  In addition, I challenge any hobbyist to be able to tell the differnece between the D3000's "faster frame rate" and the D40 in actual use (3fps v. 2.5fps); you'd have to go to 5 or 6 fps and a higher baffle before you get a workable difference, at least for my hard-earned $$. (One of the greatest cameras of all time, the Canon 5D Mark II, barely does 5fps).  The D3000's GUIDE Mode will annoy anyone who actually learns the relationship between ISO, Aperature, and Shutter Speed and while useful for a newbie, not something you'd want to use for too long. The D3000's LCD is slightly larger physically, but the resolution isn't really increased from the D40 so the image produced isn't all that fetching; it's not bad, but it doesn't exactly add to its buy-me factor, either.  Does this make the D3000 a bad camera?  Of course not, its a good camera, but you can still get a NEW D40 for less and maybe we can't blame Nikon using fluff to try to boost its newbie/Noob sales or because it can't coax the same noise handling ability from its larger sensor.Finally, yeah, the D3000 does have a few more MP's, but so did the D40x and so does the D60 and so do MANY P&S;'s...and they're still selling new D40's (and oh yeah, the D3000 is dropping to where it (along with its great VR lens) almost matches the D40's price and my earlier arguments become a bit moot)...don't buy into the MP Hype the sales people use to sell camera's (don't be a Noob); unless you are printing larger than 16x20 posters, 6 MP is all you will ever need, and its not a reason (by itself) to give up your hard earned $$.  If you "need" things like DOF, older lens compatibility, flash control, higher frame-rate, a usable ADL/ADR assisted camera (students of photography don't really need live view...), then go for the D90 - my .02  =)

Reviews.Title: d3000 good entry level DSLR
Reviews.Author: Trophytruck
Reviews.Content: The D3000 is a decent camera;  If your looking for a camera to take photos in lots of light and mainly use outside then the D3000 will work well for ya. In the camera's defence, it is considered a beginers camera. I listed some things I didn't like while using this camera.1.)If your ISO is set any highier than 1000 the picture quality starts to diminish. In other  words photos are noisy/grainy at ISO's higher than 10002.)Somtimes the auto focus hunts and will not allow you to take the picture. (might  have been my camera, or just user error.)3.)Has small buffer, Meaning after 3 or 4 consecutive shots take a long time for the photo's to write to the media card.(this may improve with a media card with high write speeds)4.)I didn't care for the user interface with the camera. It seemed like I had to go through alot of steps to change WB, ISO and shutter speed.when I first started using this camera I thought I would like the info button, which is supposed to explain what some of the features do. However I found it to bring up more questions than it answered. (bottom line here is, you still need to purchase a manuel to better understand how WB,ISO, Metering and exposure truely effect a shot!)On a positive note the camera works great in Auto mode and the preset functions work quite well. Reviews.Title: A limited camera, overpriced.
Reviews.Author: Damien Margo
Reviews.Content: For a camera manufactured in 2009 Nikon should be ashamed of themselves. This camera does not honor Nikon's reputation. It has a plastic flimsy body, lack of auto focus motor, a dated 10 megapixel resolution, and a list of missing features such as AEB (Auto Exposure Bracketing). To me there is no logical reason Nikon would make a new camera model so incredibly dated. If you are looking for a beginner camera I would suggest something with a metal rugged body that was made in the 1900's. If you are looking to dive into the wonderful world of digital SLR photography the D3000 is a limited let-down.This camera survives with a 3-star review because it's not an awful camera. The features the camera does have seem to work fairly well. But does this really matter considering the camera does almost nothing to honor the technological developments of the last 10 years? Would you be insulted if this camera lacked features found on  $200 point-and-shoots? Well I'm sad to say this, but even a "lowly" Canon SD 780 IS does quite a few things Nikon's D3000 doesn't. The white-balance presets found in the SD780IS seems to support a wider range of conditions than Nikon's giant mess. Add the video capabilities and the ability to compose shots on the LCD found in almost every point-and-shoot and you begin to wonder if Nikon is trying to pull a fast one on the DSLR industry.A brand new DSLR should have EVERYTHING lower point-and-shoot cameras have and more. They should not in any way be a testament to ancient cameras, intentionally limited in the way Nikon has limited the D3000. The D3000 was crippled by design, on paper, so it really surprises me Nikon would allow such a camera to exist. The statement Nikon is making with this camera is "we do not keep up with modern technology".As you probably know this camera does not support auto focusing on older Nikon lenses, although they will fit. There is no video capability. You cannot compose shots on the LCD. HDR enthusiasts will be annoyed by the lack of AEB. What a party-pooper.

Ugh!Now I have to figure out how to pay $171 bucks, in 45 days, or get back a defective camera that puts spots on everything! I will never buy another NIKON. Should have gotten a Canon. I have tried Canon, Fuji and Sony and I've never had problems with spots on the lens or pictures.My daughter has an HP laptop she bought in August and a few months later the screen went out. They shipped her a box, post paid, fixed it, retained all her info on it and had it back to her within a WEEK! Now that is service!! NIKON should take lessons because I have read other negative reviews of NIKON's ways of handling their product. If it says NIKON ON IT, THEY SHOULD FIX IT FREE AT LEAST FOR A YEAR!!!!!!!!!!!I also want to note that my dad bought a D90 and his is not focusing when it takes video. NIKON actually tried to convince him he had to manually focus the camera as he is filming, even though it did at first. I call BS! I don't know what he's going to do either. GRRRRRR!!!
